lines.content: - Whether I need to write Javadoc for custom exceptions.
- Writing Javadoc for my main `Steven` class and `TaskList` class.
- Helping me edit the Javadoc for my `Storage` class to be more clear and precise.
- The AI produced clear Javadoc templates quickly, which made it easy to make some minimal edits.
- Saved time: Instead of manually writing documentation from scratch, I could focus on editing the generated comments to be more accurate.
- What worked well: getting Javadoc generated quickly, with consistent formatting.
- What didnâ€™t: the AI sometimes gave slightly verbose Javadoc, so I trimmed it down.
- An estimate of 1 to 1.5 hours, as the TaskList class is the longest and requires the most Javadoc.
* Represents the different commands that can be given by the user.
* Each command corresponds to an action supported by the chatbot.
BYE, LIST, TODO, DEADLINE, EVENT, MARK, UNMARK, DELETE, FIND, UNKNOWN
* Represents a task that needs to be done before a specific date or time.
* Creates a new deadline task with the given description and deadline.
* The deadline must be provided in the format: dd-mm-yyyy tttt
* where dd is the day, mm is the month, yyyy is the year, and
* tttt is the time in 24-hour format.
* @param description the description of the task
* @param deadline the deadline string in the specified format
* @throws InvalidDateAndTimeFormatException If the given deadline string is not in the correct format
public Deadline(String description, String deadline) throws InvalidDateAndTimeFormatException {
this.deadline = LocalDateTime.of(year, month, day, hour, minute);
* Additionally, adds a "[D]" at the front to represent "deadline" task, and the deadline at the end.
* Thrown when the user attempts to add a task without providing a description.
* Represents a task that start at a specific date/time and ends at a specific date/time.
* Creates a new event task with the given description, start time, and end time.
* The start and end time must be provided in the format: dd-mm-yyyy tttt
* where dd is the day, mm is the month, yyyy is the year, and
* tttt is the time in 24-hour format.
* @param description the description of the task
* @param startTime the start time string in the specified format
* @param endTime the end time string in the specified format
public Event(String description, String startTime, String endTime) throws InvalidDateAndTimeFormatException {
this.startTime = LocalDateTime.of(startYear, startMonth, startDay, startHour, startMinute);
this.endTime = LocalDateTime.of(endYear, endMonth, endDay, endHour, endMinute);
* Additionally, adds a "[E]" at the front to represent "event" task, and the start and end time at the end.
* Thrown when the user does not follow the format for date and time when adding a task that requires it.
super("\tPlease use the correct format for date and time. The format is dd-mm-yyyy tttt.\n\t"
+ "tttt: time in 24-hour format, do not use colon (:).");
* Thrown when the user does not follow the correct syntax for marking and unmarking tasks as done.
super("\tPls use the correct format for marking/unmarking tasks");
* Thrown when the user does not follow the correct syntax for creating a certain task.
* Creates an instance of an InvalidTaskFormatException.
* @param taskType the type of task that the user attempted to create
super("\tPls use the correct format for " + taskType + " task");
* Thrown when a user attempts to add a Deadline task without specifying a deadline.
* Thrown when a user attempts to add an Event without specifying the start or end time.
super("\tYour event from when to when????");
* The main class of the Steven chatbot.

*

This class handles user interaction via the command line, manages the
* task list, and coordinates saving and loading tasks from local storage.
* It interprets user commands and delegates operations to the {@link TaskList}
* Constructs a new Steven chatbot instance.
* @param filePath the path to the file where tasks will be stored
* Starts the command-line interface of the application.

*

This method prints a greeting, continuously reads user input,
* interprets commands using Parser, and performs the corresponding
* actions such as adding tasks, marking tasks, deleting tasks, or exiting.
* All changes to tasks are persisted via the Storage class.
* The entry point of the application.
* The base class for all custom exceptions used in the Steven chatbot.
* The Storage class provides methods to save and load tasks
* to and from local storage in the form of text files.

*

The tasks are stored in an internal ArrayList that
* is managed by this class. Methods are provided to fetch tasks from
* a file, save tasks to a file, and load individual tasks into memory.
private final ArrayList<Task> toDoList = new ArrayList<>();
* Creates a Storage instance that is able to read from and write to the specified file.
* @param filePath the filepath of the text file from the root folder
* Writes all tasks in the internal list to the specified file as text.
* Each task is converted to its save format before writing.
* Reads tasks from the specified file and populates the internal list.
* @return an ArrayList containing tasks read from local storage, returns an empty list if the file is not found
* Parses a task string in its save format and adds the corresponding Task object to the internal list.
* @param task the text representation of a task in save format
* Represents a task that can be marked as done or not done.
* This class provides methods to update and check the
* completion status of a task. Each task also has a description.
* Creates a new task with the given description.
* @param description a description of the task
* Marks this task as not completed.
* Returns the string representation of the task in a local save format.
* @return the string representation of the task in a local save format
* Returns a string representation of this task, showing whether it

*
  • {@code [X] description} if the task is done

*
  • {@code [ ] description} if the task is not done
* @return a string representation of this task
* Represents a list of tasks that can be modified by user commands.
* Provides methods to add, delete, mark, unmark, and print tasks.
* It maintains an internal {@link ArrayList} of {@link Task} objects
* that reflects the current state of the task list.
* Creates a {@code TaskList} with the given list of tasks.
* @param toDoList the list of tasks to initialize with
* Adds a new {@link ToDo} task to the list.
* @param input the raw user input containing the task description
* @throws StevenException if the description is empty
public void addToDoTask(String input) throws StevenException {
System.out.println("\tOK, I've added this task: " + currentTask);
System.out.println("\tNow there are " + toDoList.size() + " tasks in your list: ");
* Adds a new {@link Deadline} task to the list.
* @param input the raw user input containing the description and deadline
* @throws StevenException if the format is invalid, description is empty,
public void addDeadlineTask(String input) throws StevenException {
System.out.println("\tOK, I've added this task: " + currentTask);
System.out.println("\tNow there are " + toDoList.size() + " tasks in your list: ");
* Adds a new {@link Event} task to the list.
* @param input the raw user input containing the description, start, and end times
* @throws StevenException if the format is invalid, description is empty,
public void addEventTask(String input) throws StevenException {
Task currentTask = new Event(description, from, to);
System.out.println("\tOK, I've added this task: " + currentTask);
System.out.println("\tNow there are " + toDoList.size() + " tasks in your list: ");
* Deletes a task from the list.
* @param input the raw user input specifying the task index to delete
System.out.println("\tYou only have " + toDoList.size() + " tasks in your list");
System.out.println("\tOK, DELETE THIS ONE ALR:\n\t" + deletedTask);
System.out.println("\tNow ur list got " + toDoList.size() + " task");
* Marks a task in the list as done.
* @param input the raw user input specifying the task index
* @throws InvalidMarkFormatException if the input is not in the correct format
public void markTask(String input) throws InvalidMarkFormatException {
System.out.println("\tYou only have " + toDoList.size() + " tasks in your list");
System.out.println("\tOK, I will mark this task as done");
* Marks a task in the list as not done.
* @param input the raw user input specifying the task index
* @throws InvalidMarkFormatException if the input is not in the correct format
public void unmarkTask(String input) throws InvalidMarkFormatException {
System.out.println("\tYou only have " + toDoList.size() + " tasks in your list");
System.out.println("\tOK, I will mark this task as not done");
* Prints all tasks currently in the list.
System.out.println("\tHere are the tasks in your list: ");
public void findTasks(String keyword) throws MissingFindKeywordException {
System.out.println("Here are the matching tasks in your list: ");
* Represents a task that does not have a date or time attached to it.
* Creates a new to-do task with the given description.
* @param description a description of the task
* Additionally, adds a "[T]" at the front to represent "to-do" task.
* Handles the user interface and interactions for the Steven chatbot.
* Provides methods to display greetings, separators, and exit messages.
private static final String GREETING = "Hello There! I'm steven.Steven\nHow may I help you?";
assertEquals("\tPls use the correct format for deadline task", e.getMessage());
assertEquals("\tPls use the correct format for event task", e.getMessage());
assertEquals("\tPls use the correct format for event task", e.getMessage());
assertEquals("\tYour event from when to when????", e.getMessage());
